docs.snippet: Some experts are raising questions about therisks prosecutors will be running when they put Andrew S. Fastow on the stand....
docs.lead_paragraph: Do federal prosecutors in the Enron trial need the headache of calling Andrew S. Fastow, the Enron figure some view as the government's star witness? A steady drumbeat of damaging testimony in the five-week-old criminal trial against the former chief executives, Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay, has led legal experts to praise the government case presented so far. That has raised questions about the risks prosecutors would run by putting Mr. Fastow, the former chief financial officer, on the stand as early as Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: After nearly three days of calmly answering prosecutors' questions, the first witness in the Enron trial of Jeffrey K. Skilling and Kenneth L. Lay nearly broke down on the stand under questioning by a defense lawyer. The witness, Mark E. Koenig, 50, the former head of investor relations, became visibly distraught when asked by a defense lawyer, Daniel Petrocelli, about how old his three children were when he made the decision to plead guilty and cooperate with prosecutors in their investigation into Enron's spectacular implosion in December 2001.

headline.main: Witness in Enron Trial Struggles With Emotions

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and THAYER EVANS

docs.snippet: Richard Causey is seen as a possible witness in the coming trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling....
docs.lead_paragraph: The former chief accounting officer of Enron agreed on Wednesday to cooperate with the government in its case against the two leading executives in the scandal over the company's collapse, significantly shifting the dynamics of a trial that is scheduled to start late next month. In exchange for a guilty plea to a single felony charge of securities fraud and for help in prosecuting Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, both former chief executives at Enron, the accounting officer, Richard A. Causey, will face a sentence of seven years. That sentence could be reduced by as much as two years, depending on his cooperation at the trial. Mr. Causey did not specifically agree to testify, leaving open that possibility as the trial gets under way.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, filed motions yesterday asking a federal judge to separate his criminal fraud case from those of other charged defendants and to order a trial by Sept. 14. And reflecting concerns about both the case's complexity and the possibility of widespread prejudice among potential jurors, Mr. Lay also requested that the judge, Sim Lake, waive a jury trial and decide the verdict himself.

docs.lead_paragraph: The wife of Andrew S. Fastow, the former finance chief of the Enron Corporation, pleaded guilty Thursday to helping her husband hide ill-gotten income from some of his myriad financial schemes and was sentenced to the maximum of one year in prison. Judge David Hittner of Federal District Court turned aside pleas to give Mr. Fastow's wife, Lea, only a few months in prison on the misdemeanor conviction of filing a false tax form. The plea came after months of legal wrangling.
docs.abstract: Lea Fastow, wife of Enron Corp's former finance chief Andrew S Fastow, pleads guilty to helping her husband hide ill-gotten income from some of his financial schemes and is sentenced by Federal Judge David Hittner to maximum of one year in prison; Hittner gives her no fine but places her on one year of supervised released once sentence is completed; Lea Fastow is former assistant treasurer at Enron, but case against her solely involved her role in her and her husband's tax filings (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The thousands of creditors of Enron will receive a fraction of what they are owed when the company, driven into bankruptcy by an accounting scandal, emerges from Chapter 11 as two companies with new names. Enron's reorganization plan, filed early today after five deadline extensions, said that most creditors would receive 14.4 cents to 18.3 cents on every dollar owed. Some 20,000 creditors are owed an estimated $67 billion in the bankruptcy, one of the most expensive in history.
docs.abstract: Enron files Chapter 11 reorganization plan under which most creditors will receive 14 to 18 cents for each dollar owed; total owed to all creditors is estimated at $67 billion; interim chief executive Stephen Cooper comments; photo (M)
